0.1: The law of the land is the law.

text.1: What does King David in Kohelet mean that A city is like a Man?

2.1: The Holy One, blessed be he, does not rest his divine presence except on a person who is might, wealthy, wise, and humble. And all of these [we learn] from Moses.

3.0: There was a man, who had a son who would steal bundles of flax. He [the man] took an oath that his son would not derive benefit from his [the man's] possessions.
3.2: And if your grandson will be a scholar, what shall happen then?
3.4: Then he should take possession [of the estate] to give it to his son.
3.7: He takes possession to give; and anyone to takes possession to give has not taken possession.
3.9: He has taken possession; for when one takes the scarf he has taken possession, and it is to give!
3.11: But who told you that if he can't keep the scarf? [i.e. it is an effective transfer]
3.13: one takes possession of the scarf to give, but takes immediately [and gives possession immediately]! In this case, these assets, when will he take possession of them? By the time the grandson, the scholar, has taken possession, the scarf has returned to its owner [i.e. the act of transfer has long since ended].

4.0: If he said 'Konam, I'll not taste anything that entered a pot', he may not eat anything cooked in a pot.

5.0: A spring belongs to the residents of the city, so if it comes to their lives against the lives of others, their lives come first, before the lives of others.
5.1: If they must choose between their own animals and the animals of others, their own animals come first, before the animals of others.
5.2: If they must choose between their own laundering and the laundering of others, their own laundering comes first, before the laundering of others
5.3: If, however, they must choose between the lives of others and their own laundering, the lives of others come first, before their own laundering.  However, Rabbi Yosei says
5.4: that their own laundering comes first, before the lives of others.
